results.title: West meets east
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Jonathan Stedall and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this penultimate program Ronald Eyre visits the alternative communities of San Francisco, where westerners are searching for something to replace traditional religion, or the religion of science and progress, which seems to have replaced religion in the accepted sense in much of western society. The fundamental question he asks in this program is “Is God dead and did science kill him, and is science an adequate explanation of reality?” He talks to Theodore Roszak about the quest for meaning, and to noted physicists and philosophers, about the growing indadequacy of science to explain. Touching briefly on various manifestations of this search - biofeedback, sikhism, SAGE and the new physics, he concludes that the search itself is positive, even if the finding is sometimes shallow and negative.

results.title: West Germany: industrial giant
results.brief_description: Covers the regions of Western Germany and the character of the people in the various areas of the country. Surveys the heavy industries of the Ruhr Valley and the craft industries spread throughout the rural areas. We see the mountains, the Rhine, Munich, Hamburg and Bonn.

results.title: West Germany: democracy at risk?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This film examines West Germany’s actions against increasing terrorism and looks into how the country is managing the delicate balance of protecting democracy against terrorism without at the same time threatening civil liberties and the freedom of its citizens. The West German police now have greater powers, and whilst most Germans applaud these measures as being essential to preserve democracy, some claim that these powers pose their own threat.

results.title: West country journey
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films and Syd Sharples
results.brief_description: Shows examples of scenery and features which give the counties of Devon and Cornwall their attractive character. Includes the multi-colored pattern of the Devon countryside; the rivers, moors, old historic buildings at Totnes, Dartmouth and Exeter; tiny ports and naval docks at Devonport and the long sandy beaches of Cornwall. Photography by Ronald Craigen.

results.title: Werner Herzog eats his shoe
results.brief_description:
In 1979 German film director Werner Herzog publicly ate his desert boots to honour a wager that he had made to Errol Morris, after Morris succeeded in completing one of the films he always talked about. Includes footage from ‘Even Dwarfs Started Small’ and ‘The Gold Rush’.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Werckmeister harmonies. Damnation = Werckmeister harmoniak. Karhozat
results.creator_credit: Goess Films, Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion (VVF), 13 Productions, Magyar Filmintezet, Mokep, Magyar Televizio, Franz Goess, Miklos Szita, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Paul Saadoun, Josef Marx and Bela Tarr
results.brief_description: Werckmeister harmonies: Haunting and atmospheric, this slow-moving narrative filmed in stark black and white reflects the harsh political environment that is Eastern Europe. The main character, Jancos (Lars Rudolph), a visionary and an outsider is drawn to the arrival in his bleak provincial town on the Hungarian plains, of a circus featuring the stuffed carcass of a massive dead whale and a mysterious, somewhat sinister figure called “The Prince”. What follows this arrival into this already economically depressed village is quite disturbing. Using long and lingering shots, the images create nuances and subtleties that make “Werckmeister harmonies” an intriguing and beautiful film. Cast also includes Peter Fitz, Hanna Schygulla. Based on “The Melancholy of Resistance” by Laszlo Krasznahorkai. “Damnation”: Featuring Bela Tarr’s renowned long takes and bleak black and white images, this story follows Karrer (Miklos B. Szekely), a sullen and listless man obsessed with a married woman (Vali Kerekes) who sings at a local bar, the Titanik. Betrayal and conflict eventually lead to despair for Karrer and alienation from those around him. Extremely slow, beautifully photographed and quite depressing but definitely compelling. Cast also includes Gyula Pauer, Gyorgy Cserhalmi. A collaboration with writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Goess Films, Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion (VVF), 13 Productions, Magyar Filmintezet, Mokep, Magyar Televizio, Franz Goess, Miklos Szita, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Paul Saadoun, Josef Marx and Bela Tarr

results.title: Wendy cracked a walnut
results.creator_credit: John Edwards, Classic Films, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Michael Pattinson
results.brief_description: Wendy Walters yearns for the passion she finds between the pages of romance novels. Her life is not bad, just boring. When husband Ronnie forgets their wedding anniversary, Wendy stumbles into an affair with the rich and handsome Jake. All fairy tales must come to an end and even though Wendy discovers that Jake is not Prince Charming, hers still has a happy ending.

results.title: Wendy
results.creator_credit: Tom Manefield, Jan Sharp and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
Wendy has her pregnancy terminated by abortion and the film reveals some of her reactions, her boyfriend’s and those of her mother to this situation. The film concludes with Wendy emphasising the importance of communications in teenage relationships. Cinemaphotography by Dean Semler. Suitable for upper secondary level.
